item.title: FFT First
item.dc:creator: Roger Wang
item.description:
Fast Fourier Transform¶

In [1]:
import numpy as np
from scipy.fftpack import fft,ifft
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
In [83]:
N = 64 # number of points
T = 1/64.0 # spacing between points

x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi*N*T, N)
y1 = np.cos(20*x)
y2 = np.sin(10*x)
y3 = np.sin(5*x)

y = y1 + y2 + y3

fy = fft(y)
xf = np.linspace(0.0, 1.0/(2.0*T), int(N/2))

yi = ifft(fy)

plt.figure(figsize=(12,3), dpi=80)

#show raw wave
plt.subplot(1,3,1)
plt.plot(x, y.real)
plt.title('Raw wave')

#show fft result
plt.subplot(1,3,2)
plt.plot(xf, (2.0/N)*np.abs(fy[0:int(N/2)]))
plt.title('FFT')

#show invrese-fft result
plt.subplot(1,3,3)
plt.title('iFFT')
plt.plot(x, yi.real)
plt.show()

item.title: First Jupyter Notebook
item.dc:creator: Roger Wang
item.description:
Start From Here¶

In [44]:
import numpy as np
import math  
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
In [2]:
plt.plot([1,2,3,4])
plt.ylabel('some numbers')
plt.show()
In [4]:
# evenly sampled time at 200ms intervals
t = np.arange(0., 5., 0.2)

# red dashes, blue squares and green triangles
plt.plot(t, t, 'r--', t, t**2, 'bs', t, t**3, 'g^')
plt.show()

Log function¶

In [51]:
x = np.arange(0.01, 1, 0.01)
y = np.log(x)
plt.plot(x, y, label=' log(x)')
plt.plot(x, -y, label='-log(x)')
plt.ylabel('Y')
plt.xlabel('X')
plt.legend(loc='lower right')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

Sigmoid function¶

In [21]:
def sigmoid(x):
    return 1 / (1 + np.exp(-x))
In [22]:
sigmoid(0.458)
Out[22]:
0.61253961344091512
In [30]:
x = np.arange(-10, 10, 0.01)
y = sigmoid(x)
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.ylabel('Y')
plt.xlabel('X')
plt.title('Sigmoid function')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
